Using theme settings:

In theme editor i’ve updated buttons and font settings (colors, fonts, etc) but on front changes doesn’t update - any ideas?

I’m building custom theme

I feel like there are some compilation issues in the design manager or the fields.json file gets cached? Design Manger doesn't seem to like it when you make changes to your fields. I had to completely remove and rename them to get it to work properly.
<@U7SL518D6> Hi Jon, are you aware of a cache with the field.json? Is there a way to rebuild or refetch the field changes or is it done on a certain time interval?

No as far as I'm aware there is no caching for theme fields. There is caching for your css files though.

It does appear though that you are trying to use a theme field for a logo when really you should be using a logo or image field in a module inside of your global partial. That gives the best experience for content creators.

<@U7SL518D6> - Thank you, I was wondering what the best practice was for this as defining it as a field was a little odd when previewing. (Sidenote: This is for a landing page that uses a dark background so I need a different logo than our colored logo associated with our main website).

I started with a simple image field in the header global partial, but this same image is used for the footer as well.  I wanted them to be able to define the image once and have it apply in both places.  From a branding perspective, logos, fonts, colors go together to brand a theme, no?

I understand your logic.

The solution I’d use though: use a global module inside of your global partial.

Same module, used in both your header and footer.

Right now Theme fields are best for working with CSS that is site wide.

I fully get why you thought theme settings was the correct way to go. It’s something we’re honestly trying to strike a good balance on, and it’s not always clear-cut.

If we go full on “Yes put your logo there” well then you might then think “tagline is used in multiple places, there should be a rich text field for setting that in themes, because it’s used globally”

When in reality a global module or global partial  or both used together is really the better option for the content creator.
If you have any further thoughts on it happy to hear it out, as I said it’s not clear-cut and we can probably do a better job educating what makes sense to do for what.

This is where I smack myself in the forehead with  "why on earth didn't I think of that?!".  I guess because its just a logo, but yes creating a global logo module is absolutely the way to go.  Thank you!

I completely missed that themes were for CSS settings. I jumped into the fields code instead of reading more thoroughly (whoops!). This makes much more sense.

The rest of the theming has been fantastic. I am able to quickly plug in my html/css that I developed locally and will probably be done with the draft implementation of our landing page by the end of the day, including 12-13 different modules.  Kudos to the HubSpot Team.

I think there’s more we can do to educate on that in our developer docs.

Don’t hit your head too hard. Internally during testing of themes functionality I too did the exact same thing.
I can’t find documentation on how to set default styling of a core text dnd_module (background, typography, etc). Any insights or a link I can’t find? Thanks!

I’ve updated our docs to better communicate about a couple of related things to this.
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/building-blocks/themes#fields-json>
You can't add custom modules within another module. the only option is to add your customizations to the theme module or replace it with a clone of your existing custom button module.
